DOC.HEAD: Peace Activists Believe Israel Intends to Thwart Rally Plans
Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with women's peace march, clash with police, arrests; picks up 5th pvs, `Organizers of...'
DOC.TEXT: A peace march by about 3,000 European, Israeli and Palestinian women ended today in a violent confrontation with police after an outlawed Palestinian flag was raised in protest. Police said 16 women were detained, most of them Palestinians. Police sprayed the area with tear gas, and reporters saw women kicked, struck with nightsticks and dragged to police wagons. One women shouted ``Peace! Peace! Peace!'' as police dragged her by her hair. Among those detained was Dacia Valent, an Italian citizen who is a member of the European Parliament. She was taken into custody after protesting the arrests to police. The women's peace march, which wound through city streets from Jewish west Jerusalem to Arab east Jerusalem, was one of several major events planned to precede Saturday's ``human chain'' around the old, walled city. Police moved in to disperse the demonstrators after a Palestinian flag was raised in the courtyard of a theater in east Jerusalem. It was unclear who raised the flag, but Palestinian women in the courtyard immediately took up chanting ``Israel No, PLO!'' and other anti-Israeli slogans. This morning, soldiers set up checkpoints on roads from the West Bank, increasing rally organizers' fears that the army intended to block Palestinians from joining with Israelis and the 1,200 Europeans in Saturday's ``human chain.'' Authorities have denied visas, barred visits to Palestinian refugee camps and blocked tour buses from traveling to West Bank cities. Army spokesmen said the checkpoints were not intended to close off the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, they have refused comment on Israeli news reports they will do so Saturday. Organizers of the ``1990 _ Time for Peace'' rally say their goal is to foster dialogue between Arabs and Jews. ``We have emphasized that we are here to support the peace voices on both sides,'' said Chiara Ingrao, an organizer from the Italian Peace Association. Israeli officials said, however, that they fear the activists' visit could spark more violence in the 2-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``The army frowns on people trying to make political statements, especially those who are not citizens of the country, in the territories,'' said one army official, who insisted on anonymity. The activists' vision of peace is at odds with the Israeli government's view on three points; the activists call for negotiations with the PLO, an international Middle East peace conference and establishment of a Palestinian state alongside Israel. Janet Aviad, a spokeswoman for the Israeli group Peace Now, a sponsor of the rally, said the government is ``afraid of European pressure and American pressure, and this event covered by the press has potential for international pressure.'' The Europeans include about 900 from Italy and smaller delegations from Great Britain, West Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland, as well as some Palestinian-Americans. Other sponsors include groups from Italy, Holland and Britain, and local Palestinian activists. Late Wednesday night, police searched the corridors of the Europeans' headquarters hotel. Police spokesman Avi Zelba said the searches ``in principle were not related to their visit'' but were aimed at apprehending a wanted Palestinian. Israel radio reported Thursday that Moslem fundamentalists from the Islamic Jihad group issued threats in Sweden and Italy for people not to participate in a rally that encouraged Jewish-Arab cooperation. However, rally organizers issued a statement saying they consider the threats ``untrustworthy and unfounded.''
